subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Not-for-Profit Organisations

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer.

question.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! That is not an appropriate way to greet a questioner announcing to whom she is addressing a question.

—Is it true that not-for-profit organisations like the Women's Electoral Lobby will have to pay the GST on membership subscriptions, donor schemes, training programs and publication programs that they now have to completely rely on to raise operating funding, given that WEL has been effectively defunded by this government?

—Let me say in relation to WEL and non-profit bodies that this government is creating a new tax system which will be of benefit to non-profit bodies, will be of benefit to charities, will be of benefit to businesses and will be of benefit to families. This is a great new tax reform that we are bringing in. In relation to the defunding of WEL, that is a question you would have to pass to Senator Newman. Senator Newman and I often do a handball, and I regret to say that after all this time you have asked me a Senator Newman question. Because it is the last day, we hope, of question time and because we like to help Labor senators, I would say in relation to the defunding of WEL that I think Senator Newman has explained that extremely well in this chamber, if I may say so.
—It would help them to be even more effective.
—Indeed. Senator Newman wants WEL to be even more effective. My understanding is that there have been consultations with Senator Newman's department on this and we wish WEL well.

—Thank you for laughing. This is the season of goodwill and that is why we wish WEL well. Madam President, in relation to non-profit bodies, you would be aware that there are levels at which bodies have to register and levels at which they do not have to register. Of course, I know nothing about the overall finances of WEL and whether they would be a body that is registered or whether they would be a body that is not registered. You are looking confused, Senator Mackay.
—Senator, you should direct your remarks to the chair.

—In order to be more specific in relation to the answer, you might tell me whether WEL will make a decision whether to register or not. Senator Faulkner has been passing the line to you. This rather implies that Senator Mackay does not actually know what I am talking about. If you could provide me with the information, Senator Mackay, I will see what I can do to respond.
—You should know this.
—I do not know whether WEL is going to be a registered body or not. Do you?
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. We are very confused. Perhaps you can illuminate it for us, Minister.
—Senator Mackay, you should direct your question to the chair, and not across the chamber.

—Thank you, Madam President. The supplementary question is: is it true that not-for-profit organisations like WEL will now have to pay the GST on membership subscriptions, donor schemes, training programs and publication programs? Could you please answer that?

—I do not think that Senator Mackay has got the point I was making. WEL may be a non-registered body. They may not register for the GST. They may therefore not have the income levels which would require them to be inside the system or not. That is a matter that WEL is going to have to decide. Until you can provide me with that specific information, it is very hard to give a specific response. Will they be registered or not? That is the question.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of former New South Wales senator Mr Wheelwright. I welcome you to the Senate on your visit to the national capital.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Will the minister inform the Senate how the coalition government's excellent economic management has helped improve job opportunities for all Australians and how the government's business and personal tax reforms will ensure that Australian families will be even better off by Christmas 2000?

—I thank Senator Tierney for that important question. Before I commence my answer, may I mention that we are very fortunate today to have in the gallery Mr Bernie Finn, the former member for Tullamarine. I welcome seeing him there.

answer.para: It is an important question. As we are preparing for the festive season, I think we can all take a little bit of time at this question time to reflect on what is happening in the economy and how it will impact on Australian families. Today many Australians received an early Christmas present in that the unemployment rate has fallen quite dramatically. I am very pleased to announce to the Senate chamber that the unemployment rate for November is 6.7 per cent. This is the lowest rate for almost a decade. Let me remind Labor senators that this is a very significant fall from the 8.5 per cent unemployment rate that we inherited when we came into office. Indeed, the level of unemployment rose to a record level of 11.2 per cent when Mr Beazley was a very senior member of the Labor ministry.

I think that if you were to ask many Australians what a government could really do to assist them, not only at Christmas but in the years ahead, they would say, `Get the economy right.' We have had another confirmation of that today with the very sharp fall in the unemployment rate. Over half a million jobs have been created under the coalition government and this has happened in conjunction with an increase in real wages. It is to the eternal shame of the Labor Party that in quite a number of years real wages actually fell during the 13 years of the Labor government. I think the overall average rise was minuscule.

talk.start.para: —Order! There are senators conducting a conversation across the chamber. It is not only noisy and disruptive, it is disorderly.

—Thank you, Madam President. This is a government which is getting the fundamentals right, which is delivering real gains to Australians—real gains in the sense of more jobs, real gains in the sense of falling unemployment, real gains in the sense of real rises in wages—and of course this government has presided over a very sharp fall in the level of interest rates that we inherited from the failed Keating government when we came into office.

answer.para: Families have benefited very substantially from the fall in mortgage rates. We have been able to bring the economy through the Asian financial crisis, perhaps the major financial crisis since World War II. That is a great achievement and of course Australians have benefited, and of course next year we will be bringing in even more important gains to Australian families. In fact, if Senator Tierney may be prevailed upon to ask me a supplementary question, I may go through those reforms.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question of Senator Kemp. Minister, can you tell us how the government's business and personal tax reforms will ensure that Australian families are even better off from Christmas 2001 and beyond?

—Thank you again, Senator Tierney, for that important question. The new business tax system will be very positive for Australian business and of course very positive for all the Australian community, and that includes those millions of shareholding Australians for whom it will provide a substantial reduction in the capital gains tax rate and a lower tax rate for small business. In the year 2000 Australians will be receiving a very early Christmas present when on 1 July we deliver the largest income tax cuts in Australian history—some $12 billion of tax cuts which will translate into benefits for the average family. Many will benefit in the order of $40 to $50 per week. This is a huge achievement and, as I said, it is another important initiative from this government to look forward to. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Service Tax: Disability Services

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Is the minister aware of the meaning and intent of the following tax ruling:

question.para: If the disability service business produces commercial supplies, then those supplies will be subject to GST.

Doesn't this clear ruling from the tax office mean that services which provide supported employment to people with disabilities and which produce commercial supplies—such as the packets of lollies sold at Christmas time, ironing services and plants sold in local nurseries—will all carry the Howard-Lees GST liability?

talk.start.para: —As our leader, Senator Robert Hill, always says, you know you are in trouble when Senator Lundy asks a question!
—Senator Kemp, that is not the appropriate way to start answering a question.

—Thank you, Madam President. A very important point was made today on the radio which I wish to share with Senator Lundy and the other Labor senators. Mr Hugh Wirth of the RSPCA made a comment about the Labor Party's `scare campaign'—and this is the truth. We are witnessing this from the Labor Party, a party which has no policies, has no intention of developing any policies and is simply determined to get out and scare people who are trying to help the disadvantaged in this community. It is really quite appalling, Senator Lundy, and I am surprised that you would lend yourself—
—Senator Kemp, you should not be directing your answer across the chamber.

—As I said—through you, Madam President—I am very surprised that some of the Labor senators are prepared to lend themselves to a scare campaign. The general principle, Senator, is that if they are commercial supplies they will be subject to GST; non-commercial supplies will not be subject to GST.

answer.para: The question is of course whether the examples you have given are commercial supplies or not. They may well be non-commercial supplies. That is a matter for the organisation. If the organisation is unsure, what the organisation would do is check with the tax office. But, Senator, I would want to see whether they were commercial supplies. In fact they may well be non-commercial supplies, and if they are non-commercial supplies they will not be subject to the GST.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does this mean that the government will now be taking its cut from the money raised by people with disabilities through the operation of the Howard-Lees GST, purely on the grounds that these industries are able to provide viable commercial competition?

—Madam President, the supplementary was written before the answer. I have constantly urged Labor senators to listen very carefully to the answer in case they have a supplementary—and we are always happy to take supplementaries because if we can provide any further help that is what we will seek to do.

answer.para: Senator, you did not deal with the issue of whether the particular supplies that they are making are commercial supplies or non-commercial supplies. Until that can be determined, I suspect many of them may well be non-commercial. That is a matter of fact which would have to be determined by the organisation. If the organisation had any doubts, the organisation would then seek advice from the tax office.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, my question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Will the minister inform the Senate to what extent today's excellent labour figures—down to 6.7 per cent—are the result of increased flexibility in workplace relations and modernisation of the Australian economy? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy approaches that might jeopardise the improved assistance to workers to balance their work and family commitments under the coalition government?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —They are indeed excellent figures. The figure of 6.7 per cent represents the lowest level since 1990. It is no accident that we have achieved this remarkable result. It is by dint of hard work. It has been in the face of entrenched opposition from those opposite and it has been in recognition of the need to put people first. There are of course a couple of alternative nostrums out there in the marketplace and it is worth just looking at what might happen if you went down some of those paths.

answer.para: On PM the other night, for example, I heard Dr Kim Howells, one of the leaders of the miners strikes back in the 1980s, who was right at the coalface and who understood what was involved in all of those debilitating strikes that turned out to be utterly futile and counterproductive. He is now the Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Competition and Consumer Affairs. When he was asked whether he had any advice for Kim Beazley, he said:

I will have something very controversial to say now. We were the party that had been dominated very much by the trade unions, by the producers. We fought to overturn all of that. We realise we have to represent everyone in society, not just the producers, and that is a hell of a difference.
He was asked: do you think the ALP should break the nexus with the unions as the British Labour Party did? He said:

Well the philosophy has to change, really. The philosophy of our Labour government is making sure that consumers, ordinary people, get the best deal, and that means we take on whoever tries to stop them and it doesn't matter who they are.
In other words, that is code for saying, `We are prepared to stand up to the unions. We are going to put Australia first. We are going to put consumers first.'

That is a very different approach to that of the current Leader of the Opposition, who reported back to head office the other day: he went to the ACTU council meeting to deliver his annual report to shareholders. This is what he had to say:

The Labor Party has this commitment to collectivism as a foundation block of its industrial relations platform. The next Labor government will have this commitment as the core of its industrial relations policy.
What a quaint socialist term. It might qualify you for honorary life membership of the Fabian Society, but it is impossible to imagine what relevance it has to contemporary Australia.

The relevance is that it simply delivers the goods. It is promising a future dividend stream back to those who were the beneficiaries of in excess of $100 million during the lifetime of the last Labor government. It is a tragic capitulation to those who pull the strings. That is not going to be the way to high productivity or high growth. The Blair government has taken the high road. The Beazley Labor opposition wants to take the low road. We all know where it will end. It will end in tears. It will end in consumers rising up and revolting, as they did last time around, because they know that they are coming last and their interests are not being considered at all.

As we enter the next millennium, for Labor this last millennium will end not with a bang but with a wimp—the City Tucker Man who, of course, has no policies and who will be desperately hoping that Simon Crean will carve up only one turkey over Christmas. What we really want is for the Labor Party to come back in the new year with a serious commitment to putting Australia first, not simply being determined to hand over massive amounts of money in return for political donations and not being interested in returning to collective bargaining but recognising that productivity matters and that people will benefit if they can take a stake in the enterprise. You went out there and supported the changes to the capital gains tax regime; I bet you go back to the trade union movement and tell them you did not really mean it at all and you appeal that as well.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Disability Services

talk.start.para: —Madam President, my question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware of the recent statement by Learning Links—an organisation that helps kids with learning disabilities—that, as a result of the GST, `in dollar terms, Learning Links will lose $16,850 next year and in a full year over $33,000. This translates to a loss of 308 hours of therapy and educational counselling as well as the possible cancelling of one of our services'? Does the minister have any response to this important organisation directly equating the loss of therapy and counselling hours, and the closure of services, to the effects of the Howard-Lees GST?

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. That sounds horribly like a question to do with education. I know the Labor Party is having great trouble working out who to direct its questions to but at the very least it ought to indicate what relevance it has to Senator Newman's responsibilities.
—I thought it was a matter relating to disabilities and I will allow the question.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Madam President, it is obviously hard to get through to the opposition that my responsibilities in relation to disabilities are disability employment services and disability income support. They are not taxes on disability services and they are not education matters for people with disabilities. They are handled by others.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am a bit intrigued by that answer because it is clearly in relation to your portfolio area. Apart from that very strange answer, is the minister unaware that her so-called seminal speech on welfare policy highlights the importance of the interface between the tax and welfare systems?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Yes, it does. I am glad you have read it.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware that the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal has more than 330 matters waiting to be heard? Isn't it the case that, before the Federal Court judgment in 1997 wound back the tribunal's function, the budget was $2.2 million but then dropped to the current level of $1.6 million? Why was the budget not increased again in June this year when the powers of the tribunal were restored by the High Court? Minister, if your government is really serious about restoring confidence in the superannuation system, when are you going to agree to properly fund the tribunal to clear this backlog?

—Thank you, Senator Allison, for the question on superannuation. The truth of the matter is that there is great confidence in superannuation. We are seeing it in the sense that superannuation is growing at very rapid rates. It is truly one of the growth sectors—
—I rise on a point of order, Madam President. The Assistant Treasurer has not understood my question. It is about the tribunal, not about superannuation contributions.
—I am sure the minister has time to deal with the question.

—On the point of order, I want to make this clear: it was a discussion on whether I could restore confidence in superannuation. Senator, let me assure you that I will be getting to the nub of your question, but I wanted to deal with the problem of whether or not there was confidence in superannuation. It is because of the remarks that Senator Allison made that I started off my answer in that fashion.

answer.para: As I was saying, by any measure there is great confidence in superannuation. It is one of the great growth sectors in the Australian economy. It does not matter whether you are looking at, as Senator Sherry has said, the SG level, which is showing a great growth rate, or at the voluntary contributions, which from memory are growing at an even faster rate. I think Senator Sherry and I would agree that that is a very good and healthy sign. If you looking at the number of DIY funds which are being established, you would say that a lot of people are showing great confidence in superannuation and believe that the benefits of superannuation, particularly the tax concessions, are important.

In relation to the backlog of complaints, I have got a brief from Mr Joe Hockey, who is the minister responsible for this. Let me say to you on this matter that the government is fully committed to ensuring superannuation fund members continue to have access to an efficient and effective alternative dispute resolution mechanism. Let me make it clear that the government is committed to ensuring the tribunal is appropriately staffed and funded to carry out its functions. The government is currently in the process of making additional appointments to the tribunal to ensure that the complaints on hand are dealt with effectively and quickly. Mr Hockey has authorised me to say that the government expects to be in a position to announce additional appointments to the tribunal once the appointment processes are complete.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has gone some way to answer my question but has not answered the fundamental question of the budget. Will the budget be increased? Can I remind the minister that there has been an increase of 27 per cent in complaints in the five months since the High Court decision, compared with the same period in 1998, and some of these complaints are three to four years old. I understand about new appointments, but the question is: is there the budget to cover the additional work which is required in the tribunal to clear the backlog?

—Senator Allison made the point that there was a backlog created by the Federal Court decision. Senator, let me make it clear that the government is strongly committed to ensuring that the tribunal is appropriately staffed and, let me stress, appropriately resourced to carry out its duties. This is a government which is very committed to the superannuation sector. We believe it is a great thing that it is one of the growth sectors in the Australian economy. We expect and we hope that it will continue to be a great growth sector. We also recognise the importance of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal.

—My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware of the tax ruling concerning vouchers that are provided to poor families to help them buy the necessities of life and to pay bills? It states, `The introduction of the GST may mean that a voucher will purchase less of some items.' In light of this, next year when the minister's department is handing out the Christmas emergency relief grants to community organisations, will this minister be increasing all grants so that vouchers can retain their full value at local shops?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I am aware of claims to that effect, and I do have a brief somewhere amongst all this paper which I would be delighted to share with the opposition. I have now found what number it is. It happens to be about No. 48 of my briefing notes.

—Order! The level of sledging that has been going on in the chamber this week is absolutely unacceptable, and I can assure you that it is not appreciated by people who have been listening to question time.
—I am sure that the opposition is really in search of information, and I would not want to hold it back from them. I will get it by the end of question time; I will present it to them then.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thought for a moment that the minister had broken her duck, but that was not the case. Surely, Minister, you have got an answer to the core issue, which is: won't you be providing less aid to struggling families at Christmas unless you increase the grants to compensate for the GST? Surely you can give us an answer to that.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I can point out two things: one is that that tax ruling you quoted from—and I am sure you quoted selectively, because it is your usual practice—said `may'; and, secondly, the vouchers that are used for fresh foods for example—and that is the majority of stuff that people are buying at Christmas—will carry no GST whatsoever, so the voucher would then have full value.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Hill. Has the minister seen reports of the current situation in Ambon, including at least 27 deaths, dozens wounded, houses and churches looted and destroyed and about 3,000 people made homeless? Does the minister have any up-to-date information on Ambon? Is the government raising this issue directly with Indonesia or in any international forums?

—The reports that Senator Bourne was referring to are very recent, so our information does not update them to any extent. But I think it is worth remembering that this is another sad event in an unsatisfactory circumstance that has now been taking place for some time. Since the end of July, as a result of Muslim-Christian clashes, it has been suggested that the death toll could be somewhere between 500 and 1,000 people. The numbers that might have been dispossessed could be anything up to about 50,000. So in terms of calamities of this type around the world, this is a very serious circumstance and one that should be remembered, notwithstanding that our attention has tended to focus on other difficult issues in relation to Indonesia—in particular, Timor.

answer.para: Throughout this period, the Australian government has continued to press both the civil and the defence authorities to bring order to Ambon but to do it in a way that is sensitive to the ethnic and religious difficulties that are being experienced. There is little more that we can do in that sense other than to monitor the situation and to urge that the Indonesian authorities take appropriate action.

We can assist, as we have been doing, in the humanitarian efforts. Although the vast part of our resources that we have been dedicating to such objectives have been to other parts of Indonesia and to East Timor, we have nevertheless been contributing support directly to Ambon and to the neighbouring Kai islands. I refer in particular to the sum of $1 million that we contributed towards food, clothing and medical supplies. We are also indirectly supporting humanitarian efforts in Ambon through our support of the International Red Cross and the other international agencies that are trying to assist people in Ambon in these difficult circumstances.

I suppose if we were looking for some hope, the best sign of it is the recent reports that President Wahid is about to visit Ambon in an effort to promote peace between the warring Christians and Muslims. He reportedly has said that it is time for a new attempt to be launched to broker peace. I think we can draw from that that not only are the circumstances being recognised by the leadership within Indonesia—again, notwithstanding the fact that they are focused on so many difficult issues at this time—but also they are prepared to take actions to try to bring about a cessation of the violence and a stabilisation in the hope that people can in fact return to their homes and live peacefully and safely. So we continue to monitor, we continue to urge the Indonesian authorities to take appropriate action and we continue our support through humanitarian efforts. No doubt we would like to do more, but there is not a lot more that we can in fact do.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Charitable Organisations

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. By applying the Howard-Lees GST to the commercial and fundraising activities of charities, how much revenue does the government expect to raise?

—As I indicated, there are rules that govern the application of the GST. If it is a commercial supply and the organisation is a registered organisation, it will be subject to GST. In relation to the amount of money, I do not have any figures here that can assist you.
—Oh, no figures? How much—you don't know?

—If Senator Cook was concerned about this issue, he could have said that he was seeking some figures and then I may have seen whether it was possible to get those figures for him. But Senator Cook did not do that. I am a little surprised by the question from Senator Cook. In fact, I am very surprised by the question because Senator Cook is a man of unusual courage compared with most of his colleagues. I do not always praise Senator Cook in this chamber, but he is a man of unusual courage compared with most of his colleagues. Senator Cook went on record a number of years ago—
—Not the famous quote!

—No, it is not the famous quote; it is another quote. Senator Cook went on record and said that he wanted to make it clear that the Labor Party is a high taxing party. Senator Cook, most of your colleagues would not be so frank.
—Order! Senator Kemp, you have strayed somewhat from the question.
—Madam President, the question was about the revenues which are gained by taxation. I am looking at the question.
—If you don't know, sit down.

—Senator Faulkner is lurching from side to side, and it is a bit hard to see who to respond to when I am being distracted by Senator Faulkner. The point I make to you, Senator Cook, is that when you come into this chamber and you ask about taxation, we on this side always remember that you have indicated that your party is a high taxing party. I will respond in a similar way to you. I have a different view of the world, and I am prepared to go on record and say that the Liberal Party and the National Party are parties that believe in lower taxes, not higher taxes.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. My question was: by applying the Howard-Lees GST to the commercial and fundraising activities of charities, how much revenue does the government expect to raise? That is the question. I would be grateful if the minister could answer it and, if he cannot answer it, take it on notice and tell us he will get back to us with the answer. All the rest of what he is now saying has nothing to do with the question. If you cannot answer it, don't evade it; just admit it.
—I draw your attention to the question, Senator Kemp.

—Madam President, I thought I had answered it, to be quite frank. I said that Senator Cook did not have the courtesy to indicate that he was going to ask an extraordinarily detailed question involving some calculations, and it is not surprising that I have come down to this chamber without that sort of detail that Senator Cook has requested. Senator Cook raised the issue of taxation, and I believe, Madam President, that I am responding in the general area of taxation. Senator Cook was worried about the taxation of commercial supplies, and what I am saying to him is that it is an unusual question to come from Senator Cook—a man who, above all, believes that the Labor Party is a high tax party. I want to go on record and say that the Liberal and National parties believe in lower taxes, not higher taxes.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I must say that I do not approach this with great expectation of an answer, but I will try. This is questions without notice and Senator Kemp is the Assistant Treasurer and this matter has been in the news for a week. Will the Assistant Treasurer take my question that I have just asked him on notice and give us an answer? Assistant Treasurer, by applying the GST to the commercial and fundraising activities of charities, how much revenue will be raised compared with the amount of government grants made to the same charities?

—Senator Cook wants even more detail. Senator Cook, because you have asked me to take it on notice, of course I will take it on notice. I am not sure whether the information that you are seeking is available—I do not want to raise your hopes—but I will see what information I am able to provide to you.

—My question is to the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison, representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Would the minister advise the Senate of the measures this government has undertaken over the past year to promote apprenticeships in Australia? What have been the results—
—Is this part of the Christmas spirit?
—Order! That sort of comment is not relevant to what is going on and it is disorderly.

—What have been the results of these initiatives and how do they compare with the previous government's initiatives? How have these initiatives helped young Australians and people in rural and regional Australia?

—Our initiatives in training have done a great deal for young people in Australia both in the metropolitan areas and in regional Australia. When this government came to power we had to do a great deal about training because it was not in a good state. I am glad that Senator Tchen asked what we have done this year. In June 1999 there were an estimated 244,000 people involved in a contract of training. That is an increase of 26 per cent on last year. In bringing about this result we have done many things. Firstly, we have the flagship of our training programs: New Apprenticeships. This has provided unparalleled choice and opportunity for those young people—
—Order! Senator Murphy and Senator Faulkner, you are behaving in a disorderly fashion.

—The opposition might laugh, but there are a lot of people in Australia who are interested in this question because it relates to training, particularly of young Australians. They might want to take note of the new unemployment figure: 6.7 per cent. That is the best figure we have had since June 1990, and part of that is an increase in youth employment. Why? Because of our training programs. We are training young Australians, which is meeting the demand for skills—unlike when we came to power, when there was a shortage of skills. We have been addressing that. We have spent $1.6 billion on VET funding in the last financial year. We have provided $918 million to the states in relation to VET funding, and that has given them certainty in the programs that they have.
—So why is the quality falling?
—Senator Carr, I have already called you to order several times this question time.
—I hear Senator Carr. Senator Carr comes from Victoria, where the Labor state government is reneging on the national training program.
—Why is quality falling?
—Senator Carr, persistently ignoring remarks from the chair is also disorderly and has its own consequences.

—Madam President, the state Labor government in Victoria is winding back the training program in that state and taking it back years to that inflexible regime which existed before and denying opportunity and choice for employers and those people who are seeking training opportunities.

answer.para: We have also brought about VET in schools. For the first time we are seeing a great uptake of those young students who want to engage in training and also further themselves whilst at school. In fact, we have some 130,000 Australian students in just under 2,000 schools across this country who are taking up the opportunity of engaging in part-time training. We also have 300 sites for our New Apprenticeships scheme. The New Apprenticeships scheme provides centres which provide information not only for employers who want to take on someone for training purposes but also for those people who want to engage in some form of training. This scheme enhances the number of people we have in training and gives information and incentives to employers.

While I am on the subject of incentives, I might just point out the $1,000 incentive that we brought in in regional Australia for those employers who are willing to take on someone to meet a specific identified skills shortage. That spells good news for regional Australia. It provides the incentive for employers to take on people who want to engage in training in regional Australia. And we are going to do more. We are going to see that record number of people in training improve and we are going to fix the situation which we found when we took over from the Labor government back in 1996.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Donations and Sponsorships

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Can the minister confirm that if the Royal Children's Hospital, for example, receives a $100,000 donation from an individual and then, in appreciation, the hospital names a ward after that individual, that gift then loses its character as a donation and becomes a sponsorship? If so, does that mean that the $100,000 then becomes GSTable sponsorship and the Howard-Lees GST will take a 10 per cent bite out of that $100,000? Why do the coalition government and the Democrats want to punish people for supporting worthwhile causes such as providing hospital services for sick children?
—Questions ought not to be hypothetical, but if there is anything in the question that the minister wishes to deal with, I will call Senator Kemp.

—I just want to make it clear that the general principle is that a donation is GST free. If it is in the nature of a sponsorship, it can be subject to GST. That is a matter where the tax office would have to look at the specifics of the matter. If the hospital wishes to raise this issue—
—Is this your clear answer?
—No, the question is whether—
—You said it was a clear answer, but it has been nothing but waffle.
—Senator Schacht, you would not have heard it: you have been talking all the time.

—If it is a donation, it is GST free. I am not sure whether the senator is saying it is a donation or a sponsorship. That is a matter that would have to be determined. I would suggest that, if the hospital is concerned about it, it is a matter which it should raise with the tax office. Senator, I do not know whether this is a question that the hospital has put to you or whether it is just you going around, joining your colleagues and trying to create scare and fear. Frankly, the Labor Party has got a bit of a serve on the radio for its performance on these issues over the last couple of days.
—How much did you pay Alan Jones?

—I invite you to read the comments that Mr Wirth made on the radio today about the behaviour of the Labor Party and the way the Labor Party is going around attempting to scare people. The fact of the matter is that we are bringing in a new tax system which we believe will be of great benefit to charities, of great benefit to non-profit bodies and of great benefit to families. As for the specifics, the general view is that donations are GST free. But if you are saying it is not a donation, it is a sponsorship, then in that case it is a different issue. The facts of the matter would have to be determined by the tax office.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would just like to get this clear: under the new tax regime, does the mere recognition of a person's contribution by naming a hospital ward after them constitute the provision of a right for GST purposes? Can the minister also confirm that, if such a donation is determined to be a sponsorship, the donation is no longer tax deductible? If so, does this not mean that the Howard-Lees GST will act as a distinct disincentive to the private philanthropy so proudly promoted by the Prime Minister?

—The Prime Minister has proudly promoted philanthropy, and he is dead right. In fact, we have just passed some bills through this parliament today which are giving effect, despite the blocking attempts of the Labor Party, to attempts to improve the capacity for philanthropy in this country. That is what we are trying to do. If there is any specific issue that the senator wants the government to examine, we will look closely at it. But the truth of the matter is that a donation is typically made with no strings attached and, in that case, it is not subject to GST. I do not know whether strings are attached to the grant or not; that is a matter which would have to be determined. We believe that the hospitals, along with the other major institutions in this country, will be better off as a result of this tax system.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the tabling of the Remuneration Tribunal's report on parliamentary salaries this week and to commitments made by the Prime Minister for some time now that parliamentary superannuation will be reviewed once this issue has been dealt with. When will this review begin?
—I will ask the Prime Minister and get a response.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the minister to the report in 1997 in which the coalition senators said:

question.para: . . . change to the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Scheme is desirable. The scheme is now out of step with superannuation practice in the wider community. There is convincing evidence that it is excessively generous to a small group of retiring parliamentarians.

Is the minister aware of the Prime Minister's comment yesterday when he seemed to be suggesting that higher contributions justified a superannuation scheme where the taxpayers pay three to eight times the amount put in by parliamentarians? Is the Prime Minister now backing away from his commitment?

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister never backs away from a commitment. If you ask me, I do not think it is excessively generous. But you have not asked me. I will refer it to the Prime Minister and I promise the honourable senator an answer by the next question time.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Charitable Organisations

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Won't everyone who attends charity Christmas concerts this year be hoping and expecting that all of the proceeds from the sale of tickets will be going to organisations like the Salvation Army, St Vincent de Paul, the Smith Family and the East Timor Appeal? Isn't it exactly this kind of charity concert that will be forced to charge GST on tickets at Christmas time next year with the Howard-Lees skimming off of money intended for the charities?

—I thank the senator for the question. It is a very good question. I thank him for mentioning the Salvation Army. I could not believe my luck when he mentioned the Salvation Army. The Salvation Army have made their views extremely well known. Let me just share with him what the Salvation Army is saying. I will quote Mr Pat Daly from the Salvation Army, who appeared on the radio.
—Answer the question.
—You do not want to hear it, but you are going to. You asked the question and, my word, you are going to hear it. This is what the Salvation Army said:

question.para: The Salvation Army is now comfortable with the GST with the compensation that has been provided by the government. We have signed off on it more or less.
Mr Pat Daly is from the Salvation Army. The question was about the Salvation Army. You will hear the Salvation Army's views. Mr Pat Daly said this:
We believe that the government is providing adequate compensation, that in fact the government is providing funding for ongoing education.
The Salvation Army went on to say a number of things. I invite the senator to—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. Can the minister clarify whether this is the same spokesman who said he had no knowledge of any of the details and was just trying to help out? He said he could not answer any specific questions about the detail. Is that the same Mr Daly?
—There is no point of order.
—Now we have seen it all. The Labor Party senator has been dopey enough to stand up in this chamber and attack the Salvation Army.
—Table it!
—This is a first in this chamber. In the hundred years since Federation, I suggest that not one senator has got up and attacked the Salvation Army. Senator Evans will go down in history.
—Table it!

—Senator Evans, at the end of the answer, you are entitled to ask the minister to table the document from which he has quoted. It is not appropriate to sit there shouting out, `Table it!' all through the answer. There is a time when you may do so.

—This is what Mr Daly said. Frankly, I am very shocked by the senator's comments as, I guess, all of us on this side of the chamber are shocked. If you saw the faces of your colleagues, you would see that they are pretty shocked too. The Salvation Army are doing a wonderful job in this country. They are entitled to be listened to. They may not be running the Labor Party line, but they are entitled to be listened to.

question.para: We have had Labor senators standing up purporting to speak on behalf of the charities. Let the charities have their say. Again, this is what Mr Daly of the Salvation Army said:
We're satisfied that all the issues have been dealt with and that we're not going to be jeopardised in any way, or it's not going to be a negative for us.

That is what is the Salvation Army said. Frankly, for a senator to get up in here and attack the Salvation Army is absolutely outrageous. After question time, the senator should stand up and apologise.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Since this is possibly the last Labor supplementary question of the year, we will do it in the Christmas spirit and try to get an intelligent response from the minister. Assuming that 1,000 people attend a Christmas concert at an average price of $10 each, won't the government next year be skimming $990 off the money raised?

—The senator should be aware from the quotations I made that the Salvation Army have said that the tax reform is not going to be a negative for them. Did you understand that? This may well be my last chance to answer this century. Let me conclude my answer by saying that the good news about tax reform—
—The level of noise is absolutely unacceptable.

—The good news is that, of the families who will be attending concerts next year, many of them will have received tax cuts in the order of $40 to $50 per week. That is what we offer. That is what the Labor Party opposed. Let me give you some advice: why don't you go away for the break and work out a few policies for yourselves.

—I have a question for Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. To cap off a very strong year of achievements for Australian women, yesterday the government won passage of its equal opportunity for women in the workplace legislation. Can the minister remind the Senate of key Howard government achievements for women during this past 12 months?
—A good question.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —It is a good question. Economic security is very important for Australia's women. Australian women are seeing the benefits of economic security coming from sound government economic policy. There are now almost 300,000 more women employed than there were in March 1996 when we came into government. Just think about that: there are more than 300,000 more Australian women employed under the coalition and its policies. The participation rate for working age women reached a record high of 65.8 per cent in September this year.

answer.para: Today's figures show that the female unemployment rate reached another nine-year low of 6.6 per cent. Under Labor, female unemployment in May 1983 was 10.7 per cent. As Senator Ferris mentioned, just yesterday the government won passage of its equal opportunity for women in the workplace amendments. The new legislation implements our commitment to streamlining paperwork and enabling employers to focus on results for women rather than process, as we had under Labor.

The government supports the choice of women with young children to participate in work and education by allocating $5.3 billion for child care over the next four years. A low income family with two children in full-time care may receive almost $12,500 in subsidies from the taxpayer for child care. From July 2000, as part of tax reform the new child-care benefit will deliver increased assistance to families and a much simpler system. The $24 million return to work initiative will help parents or carers returning to the work force after taking time out. For the first time couples, upon marriage breakdown, will be able to split their superannuation to best meet the current and the future needs of both parties. That will help to protect the retirement living standards of older women, which were utterly ignored by the previous government.

The government has committed a total of $50 million to help prevent domestic violence. In the area of domestic violence we are focusing on preventing the harm done to children by being the witnesses of domestic violence, on the need for perpetrators to take responsibility to end their violence and, very importantly, on strengthening the grassroots and practical efforts to address indigenous family violence. In 1993 OSW undertook a review chaired by Senator Crowley. It criticised the women's grants program as making a minimal contribution to government policy making. Who can forget the grant to design women's surfboards? Some of us have been here long enough to remember the grant for women's surfboards.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left have been shouting persistently throughout this answer. Their behaviour is disorderly. Senators on my left will stop interjecting.

—Senator Crowley's review recommended that operational grants of up to $100,000 be provided to national women's organisations. It was never done by Labor, and we have done it this year—$100,000 a year for three women's organisations. We have been the first government to give grants of that size to women's organisations because we want a rigorous, broadly based feedback from women and we want—

—Order! I point out to senators on my left that there is an appropriate time to debate the minister's answer, and that is after question time. Three or four of you have been constantly shouting all through the answer and this is not helping those listening to what is being said.

—I am not surprised at the male chauvinists opposite shouting me down but I am surprised at women senators shouting me down. This government has been the first to give grants of that size to women's organisations. It is precisely because we do want rigorous and broadly based feedback from women and a strong voice for women that we have done so. We have provided over $1 million to women's organisations this year: $615,000 through OSW for 19 women's organisations and, in addition, over $460,000 by other mainstream departments to women's groups, such as nursing and single mothers, so that women's voices are heard not just in the girls' sandpit of OSW but also in the mainstream departments where they can influence policy. (Time expired)
—I think that's enough questions for this century, or even this millennium, because Labor clearly needs a break. Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Charitable Organisations

talk.start.para: —Last Tuesday Senator Hutchins asked me a question along the following lines:

speech.para: Will the minister now clarify this situation and tell the many Australians who sponsor a child living overseas as to whether or not they will be paying the Howard-Lees GST on the financial support they provide?

Senator Hutchins may have been aware that on the same day, and not without coincidence, the Prime Minister, in responding to a question without notice in another place, provided a specific answer to the question. The Prime Minister said:
I am advised that because these arrangements are in the nature of donations, they will not in any way be subject to the GST.
He went on to say:
And, as the Treasurer reminds me, they are income tax deductible as well.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of answers given by ministers to questions without notice asked by opposition senators today.

It is very disappointing that again in question time today Senator Kemp quoted from the partial transcript of a radio interview conducted on radio station 2CN by the morning presenter Ms Kathy Van Extel and a spokesperson for the Salvation Army Mr Pat Daley. Beyond a couple of selective quotes from Senator Kemp, with the usual process the government adopts in these things—the lack of transparency, the unwillingness to undergo any level of parliamentary scrutiny—Senator Kemp, when offered the opportunity to table the transcript of the interview that he is so dependent on and on which he bases a very unfair and in fact a contemptible personal attack on Senator Evans, will not front up and table the transcript of the interview. The reason he will not table the transcript of the interview in this instance is that the whole transcript demonstrates the fact that Mr Daley, obviously as a favour to the radio station, has come on board—as no doubt a person who tends to be pretty cooperative would—and agreed to be interviewed by Ms Van Extel on ABC morning radio.

I would urge that all honourable senators and any interested member of the public to try to acquire the transcript that Senator Kemp is not willing to table. We have a situation where Mr Daley, as a favour, went on the radio but could he answer any questions when it came to the detail of the GST and its application to charities. Of course he could not, not because he was unwilling to do so. I do not think he wanted to be unhelpful to Ms Van Extel or her listeners. He simply did not know. He went on board only as a favour to all concerned. Ms Van Extel was virtually forced to terminate the interview. I listened to this interview and was a little embarrassed both for interviewer and for interviewee.

Why would a government minister come into the chamber in question time and selectively quote a transcript? And why, in that circumstance, would you have a government minister, having selectively quoted a transcript and defended the government's position on the basis of the transcript of that interview, refuse to table the whole transcript? Why? Because the government minister was very embarrassed with what was contained in the full transcript. That is typical of the show that we have from the government in question time.

We have the humiliation of Senator Newman simply unable to answer any question in terms of her portfolio responsibilities. She does not now even take a question on notice. She tries to duckshove it to another minister.

Some time ago, I made a prediction in relation to Senator Vanstone being sacked from cabinet. I do not make many predictions in the chamber, but I was right about that. I now make my second prediction, that is, that Senator Newman will go, whether she will be demoted or whether she will see that really it is all too hard. I am sure either she will be demoted or sacked from cabinet, or she will just resign her ministerial responsibility. Time is up for Senator Newman; time is up for Senator Kemp.

What a humiliating performance from the government to end question time in these sittings of the parliament. All Australians, particularly those who depend on charity, have good reason to be concerned about what we have heard in this place today.

talk.start.para: —The people of Australia first heard the concept of a goods and services tax more than 10 years ago from someone whom the Labor Party no longer mentions in public. They no longer remember him except in the context of Indonesia or a livestock industry. However, he was rolled by his own colleagues who could not understand the importance of an up-to-date taxation system for Australia.

speech.para: In 1993, the Liberal Party took up this task and introduced a new system of taxation to the Australian electors. But because of the way politics work, the persons who used to support taxation reform turned around and caused enough damage so that the idea was lost in 1993. However, in 1998, the Liberal-National Party coalition, with courage which is unusual in politics—certainly on the other side of politics—brought the matter back in front of the Australian people and, having thought about this matter over six years, the people of Australia gave the coalition parties the mandate in the 1998 election to bring in a new taxation system for Australia.

After the election, the legislation was passed by the Senate after considerable debate and with the support of the Australian Democrats who, although they are not in the habit of recognising majority mandates, on this occasion recognised the benefit of a new taxation system to Australia and had the legislation passed.

This occurred last June. Why is it that, after nearly six months, the GST is back on the agenda again as far as the opposition is concerned? For the last two weeks at question time we have heard nothing from Labor Party senators except on GST and on the very minor point of GST and charity. This is a very strange occurrence; most people would not understand it. Perhaps the reason is not all that strange. I refer senators to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday with the heading `Surfer Beazley on wave of optimism'. The opening statement says:
The Opposition Leader, Mr Beazley, yesterday painted a picture of Labor riding to office on a policy surfboard creating the GST wave.

That explains why suddenly, instead of, as an opposition party should, presenting alternative policies to what the government has come up with, the Labor Party are simply just nitpicking on minor points, particularly on points which cause concerns for the most vulnerable in our communities, the people who provide charity to the less fortunate. Instead of presenting a viable alternative to Australia, all they want to do is simply create enough wave to enable them to surf through the next election. This is not going to work, of course, because they are going to get dumped by the wave.

The reality is, looking at opposition senators over the last two weeks during question time, that they were clearly embarrassed by this approach. They are clearly confused by this situation. The Australian public is getting used to the sight of the opposition leader standing in front of the public, with his considerable bulk, oozing with all the sincerity that he can summons. Opposition senators are not as good at this. We can see they are embarrassed by this because they are trying to create a wave, as it were, in a policy vacuum. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I also wish to speak to the motion that the Senate take note of the answers given in question time today because I think this is a very important issue. I think it is important that I respond to what Senator Kemp has said today because on two occasions, yesterday and today, Senator Kemp has purported to quote the Salvation Army in support of his position and the government's decision to tax charities and include them in the GST net.

speech.para: I have no problem with Senator Kemp quoting sources or any other commentary that he thinks are relevant in answering questions if they do in fact support his position. But I challenged him yesterday to table the document he was quoting from. He refused to do that because he was selectively quoting from an interview with a Salvation Army officer on the local ABC radio news station. Like many senators, I heard the interview that morning with that gentleman. As Senator Faulkner quite correctly pointed out, Mr Daley indicated that he had gone on the show to help out the producer of the show and that, while he himself was not directly involved in discussions about the GST, he was happy to represent the Salvation Army position.

What transpired during that interview was that that gentleman said the Salvation Army were happy to tick off on the government's propositions, as Senator Kemp I think correctly quoted. But he did not then go on and explain that Mr Daley was unable to answer any questions about the detail, any questions about how the GST might impact on the Salvation Army's operations, or that he was really quite flustered when asked to respond to specific issues—the sorts of issues that we have been raising in the parliament this week, the sorts of issues that the charities raised with the Senate community affairs committee when we inquired into the GST, the sorts of issues that go to the charities' capacity to deliver services to the hungry, to the needy, to the poor in our community. He was not able to assist in answering how they would be impacted upon by the government's proposed changes.

Quite frankly, it was not surprising, because no-one can. The Assistant Treasurer in this place cannot help, the Treasurer cannot help, and we understand that the Democrats and the government are still locked in negotiations trying to do some deal at the last minute to respond to the growing public pressure and the real concern that the ability of the charities and the not-for-profit sector to service the poor, the hungry and the needy in our society will be severely reduced by having the GST imposed on them.

What I do want to do is put on the record what the Salvation Army have said about the GST. I do not want to selectively quote them, so, with permission, at the end of my remarks I will table the AAP story that details their position. To quote from the AAP story dated Tuesday 7 December at 6.34 p.m.:
One of Australia's biggest and most respected charities, the Salvation Army, said today it would sign up to the GST.
It made it clear, however, it was not happy at being caught up in the tax net.
Lieutenant Colonel John Hodge, who chaired the Salvation Army's internal review of the GST said the organisation was still not happy about being subject to the new tax.
"I still wonder why we're all in it," he told AAP.
"As a member of a church and a non-profit group, we'd be foolish to say complying with the GST won't cost us anything, of course it will.
He went on to say:
. . . the Salvation Army would not attempt to exclude itself from the GST, because it would then miss out on the benefits such as being able to claim back the GST on goods and services it bought.
"You do need to register otherwise you lose the tax exemptions," he said.
He went on further to say:

. . . the Salvos were in a much better position than many other charities because the hierarchical organisation and centralised bookkeeping made it easier to keep track of accounts and ensure GST inputs could be claimed back.

There is a further part to the report. I am happy to table the document so we get a full reporting of the Salvation Army's position and so that it is not misused for political purposes by the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp.

What is clear is that, like most charities in Australia, the Salvation Army are not at all happy about having the GST imposed upon them. More importantly, they know that it will reduce their ability to provide services to the poor and needy in our community. That is the key issue. Including them in the GST net, the compliance costs and other costs associated mean they will deliver less services. That is the public policy issue we ought to be dealing with. That is what the government has to answer. Services to the poor, the needy and the hungry in our community will be reduced as a result of including charities in the GST net. There is no defence against that accusation because that is a fact. They will deliver less services as a result of having to comply with the GST. All of them are reluctant to be caught in that net. I seek leave to table that document.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Today we are hearing a further extension of the scare campaign—surprise, surprise, surprise! But isn't it amazing: Senator Faulkner comes in here—the first one to take note of answers—purely and simply to defend his colleague, Senator Evans, who made the most unbelievable and outrageous outburst against the Salvation Army that I have ever heard in my 15 years in the Senate. To think that a senator can come in here and make such a slanderous outburst against the good work that the Salvation Army does is unbelievable.

speech.para: And then, of course, Senator Faulkner continued his habitual sledging of senators, particularly female senators. The sledging that Senator Faulkner undertakes against Senator Newman is pretty jolly breathtaking to watch. Every day we see his attitude toward Senator Newman and Senator Vanstone. Opposition senators really will need to look at their leadership if they continue to completely and utterly sledge senators—and not just Senator Kemp, but particularly female senators.

Coming back to the substance of the issue in terms of the Salvation Army in particular and charities in general, Senator Evans has chosen to table an AAP story—big deal!—purporting to give the complete outline of the position of the Salvation Army. Well, big deal! If you want to know what was in the exact transcript of the interview that took place—

talk.start.para: —Table it!
—I'll table it. There you are; you can have it. There is not one single solitary thing in there that is anti the government's position on GST. There you go. I seek leave to table the document.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Thank you very much. This is exactly the position that was needed. This whole interview is complimentary to the goods and services tax, the way it is going to be implemented and the fine tunning, and has never been disguised or hidden in any way, shape or form. In fact, there is going to be a consultative group within the ATO, comprised of representatives from the charitable sector, to assist with any GST concerns relating to administration or compliance. The Labor opposition does not want to recognise that. They continually and habitually ignore it. What was said by Mr Pat Daley on 8 December—yesterday—about the implementation of the goods and services tax is precisely what he understood it to be, and he said they were quite pleased with the negotiations that had started. He said:

speech.para: It's like this. The Salvation Army is now comfortable with the goods and services tax, with the compensation that is being provided by the government. We believe that the government is providing adequate compensation . . . that in fact the government is providing funding for ongoing education.

But that is not good enough for the Labor Party. They still want to misrepresent the position of the Salvation Army. Worse than that, they want to attack the Salvation Army. Mr Daley also went on to say:
We are satisfied that all the issues have been dealt with and that we are not going to be jeopardised in any way . . . it is not going to be a negative for us.
He also went on to say:
All of this has been blown out of proportion.

How true is that? The rest of the interview purely and simply goes through the position as Mr Daley sees it at the moment. I am grateful to the Senate for accepting that. Before I finish I want to refer to two quotes from the RSPCA. They said:
The opposition says things that frighten us. They are saying things for the political advantage they may receive.
How true is that? They went on to say:
I honestly believe that the truth is that the RSPCA will be better off.
Yet here we have the opposition every single solitary day this week, last week, every other week and in fact for the last four years saying that things are not so. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —That was a remarkable speech from Senator Knowles. She attempts to play the man, not the ball. Senator Evans simply asked for a document to be tabled that would lay the truth on the table. Until now the government has refused to table that document. Now it is there and we will examine it in due course. The core point in the entire debate as it affects the relevant organisation has been put out already. What do the Salvation Army say in respect of the GST? On 7 December, AAP reports them as saying:

speech.para: It made it clear, however—
that is, the Salvation Army—
it was not happy at being caught up in the tax net.
Lieutenant Colonel John Hodge, who chaired the Salvation Army's internal review of the GST, said the organisation was still not happy about being subject to the new tax.
"I still wonder why we're all in it," he told AAP. "As a member of a church and a non-profit group, we'd be foolish to say complying with the GST won't cost us anything . . .

There are the simple facts. The Salvation Army did not want to be in it. They signed up and they now regret it. The document that Senator Knowles has tabled will in due course confirm that very clear point.

During the entire GST debate the opposition made a number of comments concerning the Howard-Lees GST and its effect on charities. We said and still say it was an inequitable, inefficient new tax which is bad for the economy. We said it would unfairly impact on low income earners, single income families, welfare recipients and pension recipients. We said it would impact on the entire community from birth right through until death. We repeatedly asserted—and there was mountains of evidence—administrative inconvenience, a host of anomalies and huge compliance problems for small business.

The government and the Australian Democrats tried to avoid criticism of their joint GST package by saying charities and charitable services were to be excluded from the GST, and that charities and welfare organisations, which provide much needed services to the Australian community, were to be exempt from the vicious 10 per cent tax. We now know, as we have demonstrated all this week, that that proposition is patently untrue. The charities and the charitable sector were told by the government that they would be looked after and that they would be exempt from the GST—that has proved to be incorrect. It is now exposed for what it always was—simple deceit.

To make matters worse, all this week the government has sought to cover up its own deceit by denying reality. On Tuesday, for example, the Prime Minister denied the whole impact of the Howard-Lees GST on charities. He denied how it was going to work in practice. Mr Howard made three grievous errors. Those errors do not go to issues of technical detail, but issues of substantive policy. Mr Howard denied, firstly, the application of the GST to the commercial operations of charities; secondly, that business sponsorships on charities would not attract the GST; and, thirdly, he claimed that if the activity of a charity was under a certain level it would not be caught up in the GST net. On each of these three counts Mr Howard was wrong in his understanding of the application of the GST to charities.
What are the facts? The facts are as was put out in a press release under the name of the Hon. Simon Crean, MP, on 7 December. He said, in response to the Prime Minister's claims:
First: `In relation, Mr Speaker, to any commercial activities, then so far as the charity is concerned, there is no application [of the GST]'
That is wrong. The Treasurer boasted yesterday about how the GST was going to apply to all commercial activities of charities.
Second: The Prime Minister suggested that business sponsorship of charities would not attract the GST.
Wrong. They will attract the GST.
Third: In a further . . . error, he claimed, `. . . if the activity is under a certain level, then they are not caught in the GST net.'

Wrong again. All of the inputs of these charities, such as their rent, electricity, telephone, transport and accounting, attract the GST, and they will not be able to claim it back. This makes the GST the largest embedded tax factor facing the charities sector.

To make matters worse, the government is engaged in a change of direction on two major fronts. Firstly, it seeks to encourage large corporations to be more engaged in the philanthropic or charitable sector by endowing worthwhile institutions or contributing to charitable causes. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
