subdebateinfo.title: Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources: Meeting
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1684)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 19 October 1999:

question.para: With reference to the October 1999 meeting of the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR) to discuss illegal fishing:
(1) Which countries are the worst perpetrators of illegal fishing.
(2) Which of these countries are members of the CCAMLR.
(3) What quotas have been set from 1997 to the present date for: (a) southern bluefin tuna; (b) patagonian toothfish; and (c) orange roughy.
(4) What is the estimated catch for the same period and species, taken by countries not subject to CCAMLR control.
(5) What are the estimates of illegal fishing within CCAMLR boundaries, both high seas and exclusive economic zones.
(6) What are the present catch certification regimes for: (a) southern bluefin tuna; (b) patagonian toothfish; and (c) orange roughy.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) In terms of the nationality of vessels (determined by their flag state) it appears that many countries are involved in illegal fishing. However Australia is not in a position to maintain a definitive list of illegal fishers and this question may be best answered by approaching the CCAMLR Secretariat in Hobart directly.

You should also note that the vessels flag state does not always reflect the nationality of the bene ficial owners of vessels fishing in an Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated (IUU) manner. The commercial interests behind IUU fishing often use countries that have weak fisheries controls, to register their vessels in order to avoid the stronger controls and international fisheries obligations of their native country.

(2) As noted in the answer to your first question, Australia is not in a position to answer this question definitively. The question may be best answered by approaching the CCAMLR Secretariat in Hobart directly.
(3) Orange roughy (OR) and southern bluefin tuna (SBT) do not occur in the CCAMLR area and are therefore not dealt with by CCAMLR.

Most global stocks of Patagonian toothfish fall within the CCAMLR area and are subject to CCAMLR conservation measures. Member parties to CCAMLR implement these conservation measures at the domestic level.

CCAMLR sets TAC's for Patagonian toothfish in the CCAMLR area. Broadly speaking the control and monitoring of these TAC's are managed and implemented at the domestic level by member parties with exclusive economic zones within the CCAMLR area and by the CCAMLR Secretariat in respect of high seas area catches within the CCAMLR area.
The following table gives figures on total allowable catches for Patagonian toothfish for both Australia and the entire CCAMLR region.

entry.para: CCAMLR Total (incl EEZ's and high seas CCAMLR waters)

answer.para: * Applied in 3 statistical areas in 1996-97, remaining areas where not subject to TAC control. Application of TAC's was extended to remaining statistical areas in 1997-98 giving rise to the increase in TAC's in subsequent years.
(4) and (5) As noted above orange roughy and southern bluefin tuna do not occur in the CCAMLR area and are not dealt with by CCAMLR.

IUU catch estimates for Patagonian toothfish include catch taken by non members of CCAMLR within exclusive economic zones and high seas within the CCAMLR area as this catch is not reported to the CCAMLR secretariat, therefore the figures detailed below answer both questions 4 and 5.
IUU Catch for 1996- 1997 was estimated between 82,000 and 74,000 tonnes.
IUU catch for 1997—1998 was estimated at 18,000 tonnes
IUU catch for 1998—1999 was estimated at 16,600 tonnes
Source: CCAMLR Secretariat—based on estimates provided by member parties.

The CCSBT is considering implementing a Trade Information Scheme (TIS) which makes the landing of southern bluefin tuna into the territory of any of its members subject to the presentation of standardised documentation.

The CCAMLR catch documentation scheme is designed to ensure that all catches of Patagonian toothfish inside and outside the CCAMLR area are taken, and accurately recorded in accordance with agreed CCAMLR measures, and are accompanied by a catch document on entry to CCAMLR party markets.

The scheme relies on a paper document that must be completed at the time of landing/transhipment. The document details the species taken, the area from which the fish were taken, the quantity of fish taken, and the company and vessel details of the catching vessel. The completed document must then accompany the export/import of Patagonian toothfish to its end destination. Before any export or import of Patagonian toothfish can take place the accompanying document must be verified by a responsible flag state agency.

CCAMLR parties are required to determine from the catch document whether toothfish seeking entry to their markets were caught inside or outside the CCAMLR Area. If caught inside the CCAMLR Area CCAMLR members should determine if the toothfish were caught consistently with CCAMLR conservation measures. Toothfish may be denied access to CCAMLR party markets under the scheme.
There are no trade/catch certification schemes in place or currently proposed for vessels fishing for orange roughy.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 21 October 1999.

question.para: (1) With reference to the $4.5 million grants program for research and public information on health effects from mobile phone radiofrequencies: (a) how many projects have been funded and to what value; (b) can details be provided of each of the projects funded; and (c) have any funds been allocated for epidemiological studies on the effects of mobile phone tower emissions.

(2) With reference to the research project which replicates the Telstra Royal Adelaide Hospital study on transgenic mice: (a) can details be provided of the departures in methodology from those of the original study; (b) what are the rationale and implications for such departures; and (c) is it the case that equipment used in this study is being funded by Motorola; if so, why.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Four projects have been funded, two of which are pilot studies. Funding approved to date totals $1.365 million.
(b) (i) Professor Barrie Vernon-Roberts heads a team examining "Effects of GSM-like fields on tumour incidence in E1-pim-1 mutant mice."
The study examines in vivo—biological genetic effects, testing the hypothesis that exposure to GSM-like RF fields affects lymphoma rates in E1-pim-1 transgenic mice.
(ii) Dr Con Stough is the principal researcher for the project titled "The effect of 900 MHz RF radiation on human neuropsychological responses".
The study involves human testing of memory, attention and problem solving.

(iii) Professor Bruce Armstrong is principal researcher for a pilot study titled "A case-control study of brain and other tumours in adults and exposure to radiofrequency electromagnetic energy in the use of mobile phones."

This is an epidemiological study that forms the Australian component of an international case control study of adult brain tumours. The hypothesis being tested is whether exposure to radiofrequency electromagnetic energy in the personal use of hand-held radiotelephones (mobile phones) is associated with an increased risk of cancer in vulnerable tissues close to where the phone is normally held when in use.
(iv) Dr Pamela Sykes is principal researcher for a pilot study titled "Effect of radiofrequency exposure on intrachromosomal recombination in mutation and cancer."
The study examines in vivo—biological genetic effects, testing the hypothesis that radiofrequency induces somatic intrachromosomal recombination (SICR) in pKZ1 transgenic mice.

(2) (a) The major variations in methodology between the current study being undertaken by Prof Vernon-Roberts et al, to that undertaken by Dr Repacholi et al, relate to better control and standardisation of exposure systems and dosimetry. The current study is also testing a range of doses, and has increased mice numbers.

(b) The rationale for the change in methodology was to more accurately measure exposure of individual animals, thus countering the principal criticism by the international radiation research literature of the earlier study. Mobile phone fields are highly directional, with different spatial orientation affecting the amount of energy absorbed. As a result, in the previous study it was not possible to determine the specific exposure levels (the specific absorption rate—SAR) of individual animals. The changed method in this study improves the precision of SAR measurement. The increased number of mice will improve the statistical power of the study.

(c) Yes. Motorola donated the special exposure tubes to restrain the animals during exposure, ensuring a fixed spatial orientation to the field so the dosimetry is well defined. The installation and related costs, along with other items of equipment such as specially designed holding cages, have been funded through the grant. The highly specialised equipment, designed and manufactured by Motorola to obtain as close to "real life" simulation as possible, would not have otherwise been available.

Independent monitoring of the exposure systems and specific absorption rates (SAR) was undertaken by Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) during installation and commissioning, and continues on an ongoing quarterly basis. In addition, there is a fortnightly independent check (by the Defence Science Technology Organisation) of power levels within the exposure modules.
The provision of equipment is consistent with the initial advertisement and supporting documentation, which stated:
"Management of research should be independent of industry, although industry may be involved in areas requiring specific technical expertise or equipment not otherwise available."

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 23 November 1999.

question.para: (1) What information is collected by the Government on the practices of universities with regard to the commercial consultancy activities undertaken by their staff.

(2) (a) Has the Government undertaken any research or analysis of these activities; and (b) specifically, can information be provided on: (i) the consulting rules or guidelines prevailing in the `Great Eight' universities; (ii) in the case of each of these eight universities, the amount of money recovered in the 1998-99 financial year to cover the costs associated with the use of university facilities and resources by staff engaged in consultancy work; and (iii) the steps taken by the Government to oblige universities to recover these costs and to adjust the entitlements of staff, for example in superannuation, who spend significant amounts of their time while employed by the university working on commercial consultancies under various arrangements.

(3) What steps has the Government taken to investigate the common practice where university staff engaged in commercial consultancy avoid tax by having their consultancy fees paid to their institution, for lodgement in special dedicated accounts for their use in travel, conference attendance and other purposes.
(4) Has the Government sought the advice of the Australian Taxation Office on this matter.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) None. This is an internal matter for universities.
(2) (a) The Commonwealth has not undertaken research or analysis of university practices with regard to the commercial consultancy activities undertaken by staff.

(b) (i) and (ii) No. See (a) above. (iii) The Commonwealth would expect universities to recover costs, such as those relating to the use of facilities associated with consultancy work. Under the competition principles agreement, staff engaged by universities may undertake private consultancies, subject to university requirements. Universities were required to review their policies in this area to ensure that private consultancy services fully compensate the university for any resources used or risks taken. The entitlements of staff is an institutional matter.
(3) and (4) Senator Carr's question has been drawn to the attention of the Australian Taxation Office for appropriate action.
